cards.front: What is HTTP?
cards.back: HyperText Transfer Protocol - A protocol for transferring data between web browsers and servers

cards.front: What are HTTP methods?
cards.back: GET (retrieve data), POST (send data), PUT (update data), DELETE (remove data), PATCH (partial update)

cards.front: Describe the traditional web application model
cards.back: Server renders HTML pages, browser requests full page reloads, server-side routing, minimal client-side JavaScript

cards.front: What is a Single Page Application (SPA)?
cards.back: Web app that loads a single HTML page and dynamically updates content using JavaScript, without full page reloads

cards.front:
What does this HTML form do?
```html
<form action='/notes' method='POST'>
  <input name='note' type='text'>
  <input type='submit' value='Save'>
</form>
```
cards.back: Sends a POST request to '/notes' endpoint with form data containing the note text when submitted

cards.front: What is React?
cards.back: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces, especially single-page applications with reusable components

cards.front: What is JSX?
cards.back: JavaScript XML - A syntax extension that allows writing HTML-like code in JavaScript React components

cards.front: Create a functional React component named 'Hello' that accepts a 'name' prop
What are React props?
cards.back: Properties passed from parent to child components - immutable data that components receive as parameters

cards.front: How do you use useState hook to manage state?
What is the difference between props and state?
cards.back: Props: immutable data passed from parent. State: mutable data managed within component that can trigger re-renders

cards.front: Handle a button click event in React
cards.back:
```jsx
<button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>
  count is {count}
</button>
```

cards.front: What happens when state changes in React?
cards.back: React re-renders the component and its children, updating the DOM to reflect the new state

cards.front: What is REST?
cards.back: REpresentational State Transfer - Architectural style for designing networked applications using HTTP methods

cards.front: Make a GET request using axios
Use useEffect hook to fetch data on component mount
What is the purpose of the dependency array in useEffect?
cards.back: Controls when the effect runs: [] = once on mount, [var] = when var changes, no array = every render

cards.front: Handle form submission in React
Create a controlled input component
What is a controlled component?
cards.back: React component where form data is handled by component state, not DOM. Input value controlled by React state

cards.front: How should you handle errors in HTTP requests?
cards.back: Use try-catch with async/await or .catch() with promises. Show user-friendly error messages and handle different error types

cards.front: What is Node.js?
cards.back: JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine that allows running JavaScript on the server-side

cards.front: What is Express.js?
cards.back: Minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework for building APIs and web applications

cards.front: Create a basic Express server
Define a GET route that returns JSON
Define a POST route to create new data
What is middleware in Express?
cards.back: Functions that execute during request-response cycle. Can modify request/response objects or end the cycle

cards.front: Use express.json() middleware
cards.back:
```javascript
app.use(express.json())
// Parses incoming JSON payloads
```

cards.front: Enable CORS for all routes
cards.back:
```javascript
const cors = require('cors')
app.use(cors())
```

cards.front: What is CORS and why is it needed?
cards.back: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing - Security feature that restricts web pages from making requests to different domains

cards.front: How should you structure Express routes?
cards.back: Use separate router modules, group related routes, use middleware for common functionality, validate input data

cards.front: What is JWT?
cards.back: JSON Web Token - Compact, URL-safe means of representing claims between two parties for authentication

cards.front: What are the three parts of a JWT?
cards.back: Header (algorithm & token type), Payload (claims/data), Signature (verification)

cards.front: Hash a password using bcrypt
Compare password with hash
Create and sign a JWT token
Verify a JWT token
cards.back:
```javascript
const decodedToken = jwt.verify(token, process.env.SECRET)
const userId = decodedToken.userId
```

cards.front: What is the difference between authentication and authorization?
cards.back: Authentication: verifying who you are. Authorization: verifying what you're allowed to do

cards.front: Write a simple Jest test for an API endpoint
cards.back:
```javascript
test('notes are returned as json', async () => {
  await api
    .get('/api/notes')
    .expect(200)
    .expect('Content-Type', /application\/json/)
})
```

cards.front: Security best practices for Express apps
cards.back: Hash passwords, use HTTPS, validate input, use environment variables for secrets, implement rate limiting, use helmet middleware

cards.front: What is React Testing Library?
cards.back: Testing utility that focuses on testing components the way users interact with them

cards.front: What is the testing philosophy of React Testing Library?
cards.back: Test behavior, not implementation. Focus on what users see and do, not internal component details

cards.front: Test if a component renders specific text
Test a button click event
What are Jest mocks and when to use them?
cards.back: Functions that replace real implementations for testing. Use for external dependencies, API calls, or complex functions

cards.front: What is End-to-End (E2E) testing?
cards.back: Testing complete user workflows from start to finish, simulating real user interactions with the full application

cards.front: What is the testing pyramid?
cards.back: Unit tests (many, fast, isolated) > Integration tests (some, moderate) > E2E tests (few, slow, full system)

cards.front: Best practices for React component testing
cards.back: Test user behavior, use semantic queries, avoid testing implementation details, keep tests simple and focused

cards.front: What is Redux?
cards.back: Predictable state container for JavaScript apps. Centralizes application state in a single store

cards.front: What are the three principles of Redux?
cards.back: 1. Single source of truth (one store), 2. State is read-only (immutable), 3. Changes made with pure functions (reducers)

cards.front: What is a Redux action?
cards.back: Plain JavaScript object that describes what happened. Must have a 'type' property

cards.front: What is a Redux reducer?
cards.back: Pure function that takes current state and action, returns new state. (state, action) => newState

cards.front: Create a simple Redux reducer
What is React Context?
cards.back: React feature for sharing data between components without passing props down manually through every level

cards.front: Create and use React Context
When should you use Redux vs React Context?
cards.back: Redux: complex state logic, time-travel debugging, large apps. Context: simple state sharing, theming, avoiding prop drilling

cards.front: Redux best practices
cards.back: Keep state normalized, use action creators, don't mutate state, use Redux Toolkit, separate concerns with multiple reducers

cards.front: What is React Router?
cards.back: Library for handling client-side routing in React applications, enabling navigation without page reloads

cards.front: Set up basic React Router
cards.back:
```jsx
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Routes, Route } from 'react-router-dom'

<Router>
  <Routes>
    <Route path='/' element={<Home />} />
    <Route path='/about' element={<About />} />
  </Routes>
</Router>
```

cards.front: Create navigation links with React Router
cards.back:
```jsx
import { Link } from 'react-router-dom'

<nav>
  <Link to='/'>Home</Link>
  <Link to='/about'>About</Link>
</nav>
```

cards.front: Access URL parameters with useParams
What is a custom hook?
cards.back: JavaScript function that starts with 'use' and can call other hooks. Enables sharing stateful logic between components

cards.front: Create a custom hook for local storage
What is CSS-in-JS?
cards.back: Pattern where CSS is composed using JavaScript, allowing dynamic styling and component-scoped styles

cards.front: What are CSS Modules?
cards.back: CSS files where class names are locally scoped by default, preventing naming conflicts

cards.front: React performance optimization techniques
cards.back: React.memo, useMemo, useCallback, code splitting, lazy loading, avoiding inline objects/functions

cards.front: What is GraphQL?
cards.back: Query language and runtime for APIs that allows clients to request exactly the data they need

cards.front: What are the main advantages of GraphQL over REST?
cards.back: Single endpoint, request exactly needed data, strong type system, real-time subscriptions, introspection

cards.front: Write a basic GraphQL query
Define a GraphQL type with resolver
What is Apollo Client?
cards.back: Comprehensive state management library for JavaScript that manages both local and remote data with GraphQL

cards.front: Use Apollo Client's useQuery hook
What are GraphQL subscriptions?
cards.back: Real-time GraphQL operations that allow server to push data to clients when specific events occur

cards.front: GraphQL best practices
cards.back: Design schema first, use fragments for reusability, implement proper error handling, optimize with DataLoader, validate queries

cards.front: What is TypeScript?
cards.back: Strongly typed programming language that builds on JavaScript by adding static type definitions

cards.front: What are the main benefits of TypeScript?
cards.back: Type safety, better IDE support, early error detection, improved refactoring, better documentation

cards.front: Define a TypeScript interface
cards.back:
```typescript
interface User {
  id: number
  name: string
  email?: string // optional property
  isActive: boolean
}
```

cards.front: Create a typed function in TypeScript
Define a React component with TypeScript
What are TypeScript generics?
cards.back: Way to create reusable components that work with multiple types while maintaining type safety

cards.front: Use TypeScript with useState hook
What is type assertion in TypeScript?
cards.back: Way to tell TypeScript compiler about the type of a value when you know more than TypeScript does

cards.front: TypeScript best practices
cards.back: Use strict mode, prefer interfaces over types, avoid 'any', use union types, enable strict null checks

cards.front: What is React Native?
cards.back: Framework for building native mobile applications using React and JavaScript/TypeScript

cards.front: How does React Native work?
cards.back: Uses JavaScript bridge to communicate between JavaScript code and native platform APIs

cards.front: Create a basic React Native component
What are the main differences between React and React Native?
cards.back: React Native uses native components (View, Text) instead of HTML elements, different styling approach, platform-specific APIs

cards.front: Handle user input in React Native
What is Expo?
cards.back: Platform and set of tools for building React Native applications with additional APIs and easier deployment

cards.front: What are the main React Native navigation libraries?
cards.back: React Navigation (most popular), React Native Navigation (Wix), Native Navigation

cards.front: React Native performance best practices
cards.back: Use FlatList for large lists, optimize images, avoid heavy computations on main thread, use native drivers for animations

cards.front: What is CI/CD?
cards.back: Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment - Practices of automatically building, testing, and deploying code changes

cards.front: What is Continuous Integration?
cards.back: Practice of merging code changes frequently, running automated tests to detect integration issues early

cards.front: What is Continuous Deployment?
cards.back: Practice of automatically deploying code changes to production after passing all tests and quality checks

cards.front: Basic GitHub Actions workflow
cards.back:
```yaml
name: CI
on: [push, pull_request]
jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      - uses: actions/setup-node@v2
        with:
          node-version: '16'
      - run: npm install
      - run: npm test
```

cards.front: What is a deployment pipeline?
cards.back: Automated process that moves code from development through testing stages to production deployment

cards.front: What are deployment strategies?
cards.back: Blue-green (two identical environments), Rolling (gradual replacement), Canary (small percentage first)

cards.front: What is Docker?
cards.back: Platform for containerizing applications, packaging code with all dependencies for consistent deployment

cards.front: CI/CD best practices
cards.back: Small frequent commits, comprehensive tests, fast feedback, automated deployments, rollback capabilities, monitoring

cards.front: What is containerization?
cards.back: Packaging applications with all dependencies into portable, isolated containers that run consistently across environments

cards.front: Create a basic Dockerfile
cards.back:
```dockerfile
FROM node:16
WORKDIR /app
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm install
COPY . .
EXPOSE 3000
CMD ["npm", "start"]
```

cards.front: Build and run a Docker container
cards.back:
```bash
# Build image
docker build -t my-app .

# Run container
docker run -p 3000:3000 my-app
```

cards.front: What is Docker Compose?
cards.back: Tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications using YAML configuration

cards.front: Basic docker-compose.yml
cards.back:
```yaml
version: '3.8'
services:
  app:
    build: .
    ports:
      - '3000:3000'
  db:
    image: postgres:13
    environment:
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: password
```

cards.front: What are the benefits of containers?
cards.back: Consistency across environments, isolation, scalability, resource efficiency, easier deployment and testing

cards.front: What is Kubernetes?
cards.back: Container orchestration platform for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications

cards.front: Container best practices
cards.back: Use official base images, minimize image size, don't store secrets in images, use multi-stage builds, health checks

cards.front: What is a relational database?
cards.back: Database that stores data in tables with rows and columns, using relationships between tables via foreign keys

cards.front: What is SQL?
cards.back: Structured Query Language - Standard language for managing and querying relational databases

cards.front: Basic SQL SELECT query
cards.back:
```sql
SELECT name, email 
FROM users 
WHERE age > 18 
ORDER BY name ASC;
```

cards.front: SQL JOIN query
cards.back:
```sql
SELECT u.name, p.title
FROM users u
INNER JOIN posts p ON u.id = p.user_id
WHERE u.active = true;
```

cards.front: What is an ORM?
cards.back: Object-Relational Mapping - Tool that lets you query and manipulate data using object-oriented paradigm

cards.front: Sequelize model definition
What are database migrations?
cards.back: Scripts that modify database schema over time, allowing version control of database structure changes

cards.front: What is database normalization?
cards.back: Process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity by dividing into related tables

cards.front: Database design best practices
cards.back: Use appropriate data types, create indexes for frequent queries, normalize to reduce redundancy, backup regularly

What is a relational database?

Fill the blank:
cards.back: {{c1::Database that stores}} data in tables with rows and columns, using relationships between tables via foreign keys

cards.front:
What is SQL?

Fill the blank:
cards.back: {{c1::Structured Query Language}} - Standard language for managing and querying relational databases

cards.front:
Describe what this code does or write equivalent code:

Basic SQL SELECT query
cards.back:
```sql
SELECT name, email 
FROM users 
WHERE age > 18 
ORDER BY name ASC;
```

cards.front:
Describe what this code does or write equivalent code:

SQL JOIN query
cards.back:
```sql
SELECT u.name, p.title
FROM users u
INNER JOIN posts p ON u.id = p.user_id
WHERE u.active = true;
```

cards.front:
What is an ORM?

Fill the blank:
cards.back: {{c1::Object}}-Relational Mapping - Tool that lets you query and manipulate data using object-oriented paradigm

cards.front:
Describe what this code does or write equivalent code:

Sequelize model definition

What are database migrations?

Fill the blank:
cards.back: {{c1::Scripts that modify}} database schema over time, allowing version control of database structure changes

cards.front:
What is database normalization?

Fill the blank:
cards.back: {{c1::Process of organizing}} data to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity by dividing into related tables

cards.front: What is Unicafe (exercise)?
cards.back: Simple React app for submitting feedback and calculating averages (exercise from FSO part 1)

cards.front: What is the Anecdotes exercise?
cards.back: Small React app to display, vote and create anecdotes; practice routing and state management

cards.front: What is the Countries exercise?
cards.back: A React app that fetches country data from a REST API and filters/searches results (FSO part 2/7 variants)

cards.front: What is Courseinfo (exercise)?
cards.back: Small React app to display course parts and exercises; practice props and component structure
hints: Structure components for parts and exercises

cards.front: What is the Phonebook project?
cards.back: Full-stack phonebook app: React frontend + Node/Express backend (FSO part 3); includes CRUD operations and deployment

cards.front: Implement backend endpoints for phonebook: GET /api/persons, POST /api/persons, DELETE /api/persons/:id
cards.back: Server should validate data, handle errors and persist to a database (or in-memory for exercises).

cards.front: What is the Bloglist project?
cards.back: A full-stack blog application allowing users to create, like and comment posts; often implemented with Node/Express backend and React frontend (FSO part 7)

cards.front: Design the Bloglist API endpoints and frontend components needed to list, create and like blogs
cards.back: Backend needs CRUD endpoints; frontend needs pages for blog listing, blog detail, login and creating posts.
hints: Use token-based auth for protected actions
Sort blogs by likes in UI

cards.front: What is the Library exercise (GraphQL)?
cards.back: Full application with a library backend and frontend, showcasing queries/mutations and relationships; used as a GraphQL example in FSO part 8
hints: Use Apollo Client for frontend queries

cards.front: What is Patientor (exercise)?
cards.back: Healthcare application with TypeScript backend demonstrating type-safe APIs and complex domain modeling (FSO part 9)

cards.front: What is Flight Diary?
cards.back: Full-stack application for logging flights and notes; often used as a part 9 exercise involving TypeScript

cards.front: What is the HealthApp exercise?
cards.back: Application demonstrating APIs and frontend integrations for health data; includes authentication and structured data

decks.name: Part 0: Fundamentals of Web Apps
decks.description: Basic concepts of web development, HTTP, and browser-server communication

decks.name: Part 1: Introduction to React
decks.description: React basics, components, props, state, and event handling

decks.name: Part 2: Communicating with Server
decks.description: Forms, HTTP requests, REST APIs, and effect hooks

decks.name: Part 3: Programming a Server with Node.js and Express
decks.description: Backend development, Express.js, middleware, and database integration

decks.name: Part 4: Testing Express Servers & User Administration
decks.description: Testing, user authentication, authorization, and security

decks.name: Part 5: Testing React Apps
decks.description: Frontend testing, React Testing Library, E2E testing

decks.name: Part 6: Advanced State Management
decks.description: Redux, context, state management patterns, and performance optimization

decks.name: Part 7: React Router, Custom Hooks & Styling
decks.description: Client-side routing, custom hooks, CSS-in-JS, and build tools

decks.name: Part 8: GraphQL
decks.description: GraphQL fundamentals, Apollo Client, and server implementation

decks.name: Part 9: TypeScript
decks.description: TypeScript fundamentals, type safety, and integration with React

decks.name: Part 10: React Native
decks.description: Mobile development with React Native, native components, and deployment

decks.name: Part 11: CI/CD
decks.description: Continuous Integration, Continuous Deployment, and DevOps practices

decks.name: Part 13: Using Relational Databases
decks.description: SQL, database design, migrations, and ORM usage
